header.overview: The header defines an algorithm that repeats a user-specified target for each element in a .

macro.abstract: The macro repeats the target specified by its first argument for each element in its second argument.

macro.para:
The macro itself expands to a in terms of (s). This , when invoked with , expands to the result of the repeated invocation of the target for each element in tuple. This is illustrated by the following pseudo-code (where N is the index of the last element in tuple):
macro(s, tuple[0], data) macro(s, tuple[1], data) ... macro(s, tuple[N], data)

The target is invoked with the current (s), a particular element (elem), and, if it exists, the auxiliary data (__VA_ARGS__). This target may expand to a in terms of (s). This allows the target to recurse on itself if necessary.

It is possible to omit the auxiliary data argument altogether. This is different than passing "nothing" as the auxiliary data.
#define D (a, b, c)
( (MACRO, D,) // #1 (MACRO, D) // #2 )
The first line passed "nothing" as the auxiliary data, which causes MACRO to be invoked as (e.g.)... MACRO(s, a,) The second line omits the auxiliary data, which causes MACRO to be invoked as (e.g.)... MACRO(s, a) The fundamental difference is that, in the first line, the auxiliary data is empty (which might have a valid meaning as data), but, in the second line, there is no auxiliary data. Hence, the algorithm is overloaded on a .
Invocations of the target are trampolined such that each invocation is invoked with (s), where s is the original at the beginning of the algorithm (i.e. ()). This maximizes the utility of the .
